narrative: Post-coup Turkey represents the most rapid democratic collapse in recent history among NATO members. The failed July 2016 coup provided the pretext for completing consolidation that had been underway since 2013. Under emergency rule, Erdoğan purged over 150,000 civil servants, judges, military officers, teachers, and journalists. The 2017 constitutional referendum (conducted under emergency conditions) transformed Turkey into a presidential system with minimal checks. By 2018, Turkey had crossed multiple red lines: courts were bypassed, military was purged, executive immunity was established. Elections continued but under conditions that made genuine competition nearly impossible. This baseline represents what rapid, crisis-driven consolidation looks like.

comparison_guidance: Turkey 2018 demonstrates crisis-accelerated consolidation. Use this baseline to assess scenarios where an external shock (coup, terrorism, pandemic) is used to justify emergency measures that become permanent. The key indicators: emergency powers that bypass courts, mass purges justified by security, and constitutional changes under crisis conditions. Multiple red-line triggers indicate the system has crossed into territory where electoral reversal is structurally blocked.
